contextId.information: This probably refers to a place where trash and garbage were dumped and perhaps burned. Sitting in such a place was a sign of deep mourning. AT: "sat on the trash heap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: sat down in the middle of ashes

contextId.information: "I would be resting with princes." (ULB) In this phrase, the words "lying" and "resting" are a polite way of saying "no longer alive." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: I would have been lying with princes

contextId.information: This means for God to cause him to die. AT: "would crush me and let me die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This  to his refers to him dying. AT: "he will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This is a polite way to say that they died. AT: "They both die and people bury them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: They lie down alike in the dust

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a way of saying Job's wife will sleep with other men or 2) it means she will become a slave and work for another man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: then let my wife grind grain for another man
